document.text: Wednesday November has been desig nated as Firemens Month for the volunteers of the Appomat tox County Fire Department. Paul Drinkard and James R. Ford, Jr. are seeking donations to apply, in conjunction with the Appomattox Town Council, to a dinner honoring the volunteer firemen and to present each of them with a bonus in appreciation for their time and service to the community. Donations are slow coming in, so if you have not made your contribution to the firemen please mail it to either Mr. Paul Drinkard or Mr. James R. Ford, Jr., Appomattox, VA 24522, or give to them in person. Your contributions will be greatly appreciated.

document.text: Tuesday. . Incumbents R. C. Hubbard, R. L- Bass and T. E. Sonny Conner will seek reelection to the Appomattox Town Council. The seat on council now held by Ronald a Spiggle will be vacated as he is seeking election to the office of M ay of the Town of Appomsttox. Marvin J. House, Jr. will not seek reelection due to the fact that he has accepted a promotion with Fidelity Ameri can Bank and will be moving with his family to Amherst. Burke Guill, at this time, does not plan to seek reelection.

document.text: TOWN ORDINANCE By order of the Appomattox Town Council, be it ordained that roller skating or riding bicycles is hereby prohibited on the sidewalks of Church Street from Dr. Christian s corner to the corner of Reggie Stan leys and on Main Street from the Drug Store to Smiths Mill and living a penalty for violations of this ordinance by depriving the violators of their roller skates or bicycles for a period of 30 days by the Town officers. Effective after publication. By order of the Appomattox Town Council, be it ordained, prohibiting parking on Main Street at the Drug Store by eliminating two pre- s at parking spaces - 1C feet. document.text: Thomas W . Tommy Lawson announced toilpy that hp will be an Independent candidate for the office of Appomattox County Common- wekltns Attorney in the November election. Lawson, a 1967 graduate of Appomattox High School, i   4B71 graduate of  V irgffin rM !ltt?y Institute. He served for a short time as Second L t. in the United States Arm y. He graduated front the Memphis State University School of Law in l974 and has been practicing law in Appomattox since 1976. Lawson has been a member of the Appomattox Town Council since being elected to the office in 1978. He is a member of Memorial United Methodist Church. Married to the former Becky Dundaa of Bogalusa, Louisiana, they are the parents of three children, Alison, Mark and JIB.

document.text: There will be a contest in this Appomattox Town Council election seven candidates have filed for the six available Town Council seats. According to Barbara Williams, bounty clerk, four incumbents as well as three newcomer hopefuls had filed for the election as of thé 7 p.m. filing deadline Tuesday.  Incumbents who filed for re-election include Richard L. Bass, Thomas W. Lawson, Robert 1C. Hubbard and Thomas E. SonnyConneFr Newcomers to the town political ring include Pâtricia J. Butler, Walter H. Carson, and Raymond A. Noble. Williams said that incumbent Mayor Ronald C. Spiggle was, the only candidate to ,ile for the mayoral election.

document.text: The weeks of April 24 and May 1 have been designated by the Appomattox Town Council as Spring Clean Up Weeks. This is the time all town pro perty owners are asked to clean up all accumulation of winter debris on their property. Town workmen will dispose of debris on regular pickup days. Those wishing this additional service are asked to call the town man agers office in advance of pick up days.

text.snippet: been designated by the <mark>Appomattox</mark> <mark>Town</mark> <mark>Council</mark> as Spring Clean Up

document.text: the town of Appomattox or drill ing under the roadbed to per mit installation of water and sewage lines for the new county high school. The board plans to cooperate with the town of Ap pomattox in sharing costs and manpower to service the new high school with water and sew age lines. Town Manager C. S. Booth, Appomattox Town Manager, told the board that in somuch as he has retired as town manager, he now needs some office space if he is to continue as agent for enforce ment of the countys subdivision ordinance. Booth also holds seats on the Cent. Va. Planning Commission Technical Com - mittee on Water and Sewage and another technical commit tee on Highways for the Plan ning Commission. He has also been oarticipating in the Roa noke River Basin Survey and James River Basin Survey .The board requested Booth to re tain the position of subdivision agent and tn remain on the technical committees. They agreed to supply a small office adjacent to the Commissioner of the Revenues offices for per sons wanting information or as sistance. Voting Machines Three voting machines are now in the jury room, awaiting the fall election, according to the clerk, Mrs. Aldah B. Gor don. Resolution Read The clerk read a resolution from Memorial United Metho dist Church registering a pro test against the establishment of an A.B.C. store in the coun ty. Auto Request Sheriff Gene Richardson re quested that the board work with the Appomattox Town Council to share costs of a building, 10 ft. by 10 ft. to house a base radio system. The building will be lo cated at the base of a town water tower, with radio antenna on top. Sheriff Richardson also re minded the board that it is just about time to replace two de- partment vehicles, both of which are over the 75,000 mark.

document.text: The Town of Appomattox has purchased property adjoining the sewer lagoon and the Appomattox Ball Park from M rs. Verta Stanley, cording to an announcement at the May meeting of Appomattox Town Council Monday night. Council has no definite plans for use of the land at present but in the future if improvements to the sewer plant or ball path or additions are needed the fruMwavailsMe.  plans call for work to begin on the updating of existing W atorwaste Treatment Plant in late fall, according to Town Manager W.ILBritton, Jr . H i begin working on acquiring the necessary rights o f way as soon as possible, Britton sud. In reporting on the second well site on Court land property, Britton said, We came up with another dry well. We are working with the health department, asking that they come down and look at thè proposed well sites. Several sites north of town will be good I believe, added Britton. I plan to have the state geologist check them out. There will be no cost to the town for the geologists evaluation.

document.text: The September meeting of the Appomattox Town Council will be held on Monday night, at 730, at the town office. This is the first meeting of the new council elected last June.

document.text: The September meeting of the Appomattox Town Council was held on Monday night. New members elected last June were present, and the council re-organized, with Mrs Calvin Robinson, senior member being unanimously elected as the President of the Council. After discussion, the body voted to invite an expert from Roanoke to meet here with a representive of the State Board of Health from Richmond, to suggest ways to cor rect recent difficutlies with the town water lines.

document.text: The regular monthly meeting of the Appomattox town council was held Monday night in the Mayors office. After hearing a report on the financial condition of the town, and finding that sufficient funds are in hand, the council voted to pur chase a new dump truck to replace the one now in use. The matter of purchasing a truck was turned over to the fiance committee, of which F. L. Murphy is chairman. Upon report that the present fire siren can not be heard in all parts of Ihe town, the town council auth orized the purchase of a new and  rg e r siren. It is estimated that a siren of the desired size, to blanket a three mile area with a fire alarm, will cost slightly over 100. On the

document.text: The regular meeting of the Womans Club of Appomattox will he held at 300 P. M. on the first Monday of each month, except when the first Monday falls on a holiday, in which event the meeting will be on the second Monday. The Executive Board of the Womans Club will meet in the Di rectors Room of the Bank of Appo mattox at 330 P. M. on Monday preceding the regular meeting date. The Appomattox Garden Club will meet the fourth Monday night of each month at 800 oclock. The Appomattox Town Council meets the third Monday night of the month, at 7 30 oclock. The Appomattox Lions Club will meet the second and fourth Thurs day at 645 P. M. The Appomattox P.-T. A. will meet the third Tuesday night in each month at 800 oclock. The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Cnnfeder acy meets the third Thursday night of each month, at 745.

document.text: The new fiscal year begins July 1 and the budget was adopted after a public hearing was conducted by the board on the proposed budget on June 2. The countys real estate tax rate stands at 60 cents per 100 of the assessed evaluation. The personal property tax rate is 3.50 per 100 of assessed evaluation. William R. Britton, Jr., Appomattox town manager and ..special projects assistant to the board, told the supervisors that the Appomattox Town Council plans to construct a lagoon-type regional waste water system and that council has decided to locate it onContinental Can land approximately 1000 feet downstream from a site that had been considered. This notification was required by law. The Appomattox County Overall Economic Development Plan has been approved by the U. S. Department of Commerce Economic Development Administration, according to Britton. Loans and grants will be available to help stimulate growth and economy in the county. In other business, Dan Herncall was appointed to replace Mr. Charles R. Perkins as Chairman of the Appomat tox Overall Economic Development Plan Committee. The board heard a report from the Appomattox Planning Commission on the request to review. Poff Construc tions proposal for 48 low-income apartment units in the county. The request was denied as the county can not furnish sewer for such a complex. Glenda Gwen Guthrie was appointed to the position of Juvenile Deliquency Prevention Specialist effective im mediately. The position was approved through November 1 of this year and will be funded through grant money. Bobby Waddell, representing the Appomattox County Young Farmers Association, appeared before the board to ciscuss complaints filed after the 4-wheel-drive pull mid the tractor pull held here recently. This event first started in 1978 and is sponsored by the Appomattox County Young Farmers Tractor Pullers, Inc. The last event attracted approximately 1150 penm m -  Lawson told Waddell that they had

document.text: The general public is invited to attend an old-fashioned town meeting to learn about local government. The meeting entitled Local Government - Who? is scheduled for the citizens of Appomattox County and Town on May 18 at 8 p.m. at Appomattox High School. The town meeting is for the purpose of discussing the functions, powers and limita tions of local government. The Appomattox County Board of Supervisors and Appomattox Town Council are sponsoring the session to encourage better communication between the people and th eir elected officials. The meeting will begin with a panel discussion of the actual operation of local government. Panel members include Senator Howard P. Anderson William R. Britton, Appomattox town manager Mayor Henry Pack of Appomattox Dr. Tom Gilpat- rick, government professor at Sweet Briar College and James A. Lampman, political science professor at Central Virginia Community College. R. B. Carter, director of vocational education, will serve as panel moderator. The panel discussion will include an explanation of how local government was created and for what purposes, an explanation of how it actually operates and an explanation of specific state or federal laws which limit local governments powers. After the panel discussion, audience, participation will be

document.text: The filing deadline for Appomattox and Pamplin town elections is March 4, and residents wishing to run for town office must file .their declarations of candid acy with the clefk of circuit courts by that date. The elections for both town councils and both mayors will be held May 6. The Appomattox Town Council consists of six members - Richard L. Bass, Thomas W. Lawson, Robert C. Hubbard, T. E. Sonny Conner, Samuel Carterj Maurice E. Gordon - and Mayor Ronnie spiggle. R. C. Hubbard was the only incumbent to have filed for re-election by press time Tuesday afternoon, accord ing to Barbara Williams,

document.text: The Commission on_ Aging received full support from the Appomattox Town  Council when they met in regular session on Monday night. Wallace Clair of Spout Spring, Chairman of the Com mission on Aging, an advisory body of 15 appointed citizens functioning under the direction of the Virginia Office on Aging and Family Service Beard, appeared before council to explain the functions of the Commission. A survey taken in early 1974 by the Central Virginia Geron tology Task Force led to the organizing of the Central Virginia Commission on Aging encompassing the counties of Amherst, Bedford, Campbell, Appomattox, and cities of Bedford and Lynchburg. The survey was funded in part by a grant from the Administration on Aging and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare under the provision of the older Americans act as amended in 1973. There will be no cost at all to the Town or County of Appomattox. The goals, objectives, and recommended action steps are 1. health care, 2. day activities and service centers, 3. trans portation, 4. public awareness 5. Information ti Referral we now have a center located here, 6. nutrition, and 7

document.text: The Central Virginia Plan ning District Commission CV- PDC unanimously passed a resolution at its July meeting supporting a U.S House of Representatives Bill which could help settle the current controversy with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers over its definition of navigable waters. The House Bill, which is co-sponsored by Congressmen Caldwell Butler and Robert Daniel would define navigable waters as contained in Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. That definition terma navigable waters aa those which are presently used, or are suscepti ble to use in their natural condition or by reasonable improvement aa a means to transport interstate com merce. Controversy began several months ago when the Corps of Engineers made public its intention to expand its jurisdic tion over every lake, stream, stock pond and irrigation ditch in the nation - - this being its definition of navigable wat ers. The Board of Supervisors of Appomattox County and the Appomattox Town Council in June at 1975 went on record as opposing the attempt to extend federal control over all waters within the town and county. Letters stating their opposition were written from the Town of Appomattox to U.8. Senators Harry F. Byrd and William Scott aad Congressman W. C. Dan Daniel 5th District.  Representative Dan Daniel hai warned that regulations proposed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers expanding its authority over all water ways I the country would constitute land use planning by another name. According to the 5th District representative, under the poli cy any landowner wishing to build a structure that comes in contact with the water is required to get a permit from the Corps. Unless legislation now pending in Congress to alleviate the problem is passed, the Corps will soon need a bureocracy double its present size to fulfill the functions which it projects for itself. The Bedford County, Camp bell County, Amherst County, and Appomattox County Board of Supervisors, in addition to Appomattox Town Council and the Bedford City Council have all passed resolutions opposing the Corps expanded authority. The CVPDC also passed a similar resolution in May. At the Recommendation of the Smith Mountain-LeeaviUe Reservoirs Committee the Commission adopted the reso lution supporting the House Bill which would provide an acceptable definition of naviga ble waters to localities. In other action the Commis sion also passed a resolution opposing the changing of the effective date of the scheduled annual increase for General Registrars proposed by the State Board of Elections. According to Roy C. Mayo, HI, Amherst County Adminis trator and Chairman of the Commissions Governmental Administrators Technical Com mittee, the State Board of Elections wants to change the date of annual increases for General Registrars from July 1 to March 1. This change would create a great deal of confusion for localities since we use July 1 aa the standard date for salary increases for county and municipal employees. Budget ary complications will result if we have to work with both the July 1 and the March 1 dates, said Mayo. The resolution opposing the date change was passed unanimously by the Commis sion. document.text: The Appomattox Town Council voted to increase its general liability insurance Monday night at their regular meeting. Richard Burke with J. A. Burke  Company, 1- appeared before council to assist with answers to ques tions concerning coverage. In view of the fact that council felt that town coverage was not sufficient to protect town police, town officials and aH town employees against wrongful acts, they voted to increase coverage from 300,- 000 bodily injury and 25,000 property damage to 1 million single lim it bodily andor property to include polite liability, also. The general liability coverage has endorse ment to provide protection for town police, town officials, and all town employees from any and all acts of wrongdoing. Council frit that it was unfortunate. tha they had to increase insurance coverage to this extent but as the public so readily accepts lawsuits it is necessary to be fully protected even though the tax paying public ends up having to pay costs. document.text: The Appomattox Town Council voted Monday night to refuse a request for ft change hi the ordinance regulating game rooms in the town limits. The ordinance prohibits game rooms from operating from 11 u n , Saturday until 7 a.m. Monday and from midnight to 7 a.m. during the week. At the March Couheil meeting, representatives of Burger King and Qtttek-E Pood Store appeared before the towns governing body to ask that the ordinance be changed to allow video games to be used during the businesses normal operating hours. Councilman Dick Bass and Ray Noble expressed concern over the video erase, noting that aoose children day at the video games witb a vigor which borders oh addiction. Councilman Tommy Lawson aid he feels the children are the responsibility of their parenta and that the T om C ore should not attempt to legislate morality. document.text: The Appomattox Town Council Monday night went on record as opposing nine legisla tive proposals set forth by the States Commission on Crime and Criminal Justice. document.text: The Appomattox Town Council has designated the weeks of Nov. 25 through Dec. 9 as Fall Clean-up Weeks in Appomattox. During this period the town truck will carry off trash and other de bris not ordinarily collected. Those having trash, etc. to be removed, will telephone the Town Manager. This community effort is under taken with the cooperation o the Appomattox Garden Club, to get the tow, -in readiness for the holi day season.

document.text: The Appomattox Town Council has designated the weeks of April 11 and of April 18 s Clean-Up Weeks in Appomattox. At this tintf, the town truck will carry off trash and other debris not ordinarily collected! Those  having trash to he removed will telephone the Town Manager between 800 and 845 A. M. during this period.

document.text: The Appomattox town council  met Monday night. Bob Armstrong, of Birmingham, I Ala., who has been in the U. S. I Navy for the past five years, is vis iting his great-uncle, J. H. Cheat ham. Miss Della Inge, of Sit. Paul, Wise county, will arrive this week-end to I spend the summer here with her I parents, M r, and Mrs. T . H . Inge. Miss Mary Ann LeGrand, o f Charlottesville, was home for the I week-end. I Edwin Frazier, of Richmond spent I Sunday in the home of A. R. I Gobble.

document.text: The Appomattox Garden Club will meet the fourth Monday night of each month at 800 oclock. The Appomattox Town Council meets the third Monday night of the month, at 730 oclock. The Appomattox Lions Club will meet the second and fourth Thurs day at 646 P. M. The Appomattox P.-T. A. will meet the third Tuesday night in each month at 800 oclock. The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confeder acy meets the third Thursday night of each month, at 745. The Executive Board of the Womans Club will meet in the Di rectors Room of the Bank of Appo mattox at 330 P. M. on Monday preceding the regular meeting date.

document.text: The annual firem ens ban quet and end-of-year meeting for Appomattox Town Council was held Monday evening, be ginning with a steak dinner for all at the Parkway Restau rant. Firemen were presented a cash bonus at the dinner, result of a fund drive conducted by Paul Drinkard and James Ford.
